articles.headline: Michael Cohen Indefinitely Postpones Testimony to Congress
articles.snippet: Mr. Cohen’s lawyer cited verbal attacks by President Trump as his reason for bowing out of the hearing, which was to be a marquee moment in Democrats’ plan to showcase their oversight of Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cohen’s lawyer cited verbal attacks by President Trump as his reason for bowing out of the hearing, which was to be a marquee moment in Democrats’ plan to showcase their oversight of Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael D. Cohen, the former personal lawyer and fixer for President Trump, indefinitely postponed his congressional testimony set for next month, his lawyer said on Wednesday, depriving House Democrats of one of their first big spectacles in their plans to aggressively investigate the Trump administration.

articles.headline: Trump Says He’ll Delay Speech Until After Shutdown, as Democrats Draft Border Security Plan
articles.snippet: Democratic leaders said they were prepared to match the amount requested by President Trump, but only if the money was used for security measures like drones and refitted ports of entry — not a wall.
articles.abstract: Democratic leaders said they were prepared to match the amount requested by President Trump, but only if the money was used for security measures like drones and refitted ports of entry — not a wall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said late Wednesday that he would deliver his State of the Union address once the federal government reopens, capping a day of brinkmanship with Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who told the president that he was not welcome to deliver the speech in the House chamber while the government is partly closed.

articles.headline: How to Declutter and Organize Your Personal Tech in a Few Simple Steps
articles.snippet: Accessories and data may not take up much physical space, but they contribute to frustration and anxiety. Here are ways to keep e-junk at bay, Marie Kondo-style.
articles.abstract: Accessories and data may not take up much physical space, but they contribute to frustration and anxiety. Here are ways to keep e-junk at bay, Marie Kondo-style.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a new year and a new Netflix show that features the Japanese organizing guru Marie Kondo on the art of “Tidying Up,” many of us are experimenting with how to simplify our lives by purging our homes of unwanted possessions.

articles.headline: Corporate Chiefs Look Past Economic Risks and Pin Hopes on Trump for Trade Deal
articles.snippet: Executives are playing down the threats posed by a trade war and other headwinds, much as they dismissed the possibility of a government shutdown right before it started.
articles.abstract: Executives are playing down the threats posed by a trade war and other headwinds, much as they dismissed the possibility of a government shutdown right before it started.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s corporate leaders are shrugging off a monthslong trade war, a protracted government shutdown and other looming economic threats, projecting that revenue growth in 2019 will be strong largely on the assumption that President Trump will reach a deal with China.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: BuzzFeed Plans Layoffs as It Aims to Turn Profit
articles.snippet: About 15 percent of its work force will be cut, or about 200 employees across the company’s departments, including the news division.
articles.abstract: About 15 percent of its work force will be cut, or about 200 employees across the company’s departments, including the news division.
articles.lead_paragraph: BuzzFeed, often hailed as the future of publishing and a leading producer of digital content, plans to lay off 15 percent of its work force, or around 200 employees, according to a memo sent to the staff on Wednesday night.

articles.headline: The Hard Part of Computer Science? Getting Into Class
articles.snippet: Student demand for computer science courses is outstripping the supply of professors, creating a student divide of computing haves and have-nots.
articles.abstract: Student demand for computer science courses is outstripping the supply of professors, creating a student divide of computing haves and have-nots.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lured by the prospect of high-salary, high-status jobs, college students are rushing in record numbers to study computer science.

articles.headline: ‘We Didn’t Get Ph.D.s Just to Sit Around’: Civil Servants’ Good Will Erodes
articles.snippet: As the shutdown slogs on, scientists, engineers and other high-skilled civil servants are starting to question the appeal of government work.
articles.abstract: As the shutdown slogs on, scientists, engineers and other high-skilled civil servants are starting to question the appeal of government work.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When things overheat, corrode and stop working, that is when they call in Gustavo Costa.

articles.headline: Renault Names New Leaders to Replace Carlos Ghosn
articles.snippet: The French carmaker will focus on easing tensions within the world’s biggest auto alliance, and may seek to install one of its own executives as the chairman of Nissan.
articles.abstract: The French carmaker will focus on easing tensions within the world’s biggest auto alliance, and may seek to install one of its own executives as the chairman of Nissan.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Renault announced new leadership on Thursday after Carlos Ghosn resigned as chairman and chief executive from his jail cell, ending his reign as one of the world’s most powerful industrialists and opening a crucial new chapter for the world’s biggest auto alliance.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Russia Warns U.S. Not to Intervene in Venezuela as Military Backs Maduro
articles.snippet: The declaration of loyalty to President Nicolás Maduro was a setback for the Venezuelan opposition leader, who has been backed by several countries, including the United States.
articles.abstract: The declaration of loyalty to President Nicolás Maduro was a setback for the Venezuelan opposition leader, who has been backed by several countries, including the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The embattled government of Venezuela struck back against its opponents on Thursday, winning strong support from the country’s armed forces and the solid backing of Russia, which warned the United States not to intervene.
articles.byline: By Ana Vanessa Herrero and Neil MacFarquhar
